name: A Mini-guide to Designing with the UMD Skill
author: HipRedux

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Mini-UMD Guide

UMD is the most powerful skill available in the game.  It opens up access to gear and items that would not otherwise be available to rogues, assassins and bards.  A single late skill dump is enough to completely change the effectiveness of just about any build.  The lower the magic level of the environment, the more powerful UMD is.  Once you've become dependent on UMD's benefits, you may find it difficult to play without it.

The overview of UMD is described on the NWNWiki.  Check the value table to determine how much UMD might be needed where you play.  It's best to have a general idea of the maximum value of items you would like to gain access to via UMD before designing your toon.
 
For the sake of this discussion, all UMD ratings described are MODIFIED ranks (w/CHA modifier applied) unless otherwise specified.  It is written mainly for those who have little or no experience dealing with UMD.  It will probably seem unnecessarily rudimentary to others.  C'est la vie!

Using UMD to Equip Restricted Gear

The easiest way to determine whether your UMD level is sufficient to use gear is to just mouse-over its image.  If the image has a red halo around it, you need a higher UMD rating.  If no halo, it can be equipped.

High-magic environments tend to require very high UMD ratings because there are often multiple properties on class-specific gear which results in high value.  In cases where UMD's main intent is to equip restricted gear, always allot to the UMD skill in increments of 5.  For example, a UMD rating of 11 to 14 evaluates exactly the same as UMD 10, or a value of 20K gold.

UMD never ignores proficiency restrictions.  Regardless of how many ranks you allot to your UMD skill, unless you have the applicable proficiency by an existing feat, you'll never be able to use the gear.

Using UMD to Use Restricted Items other than Scrolls or Gear

Wands, rods, and other items with magical spell charges or uses per day require no proficiency so as long as the UMD rating is sufficient to cover its value, it can be used.  The same "red halo" marker will alert you as to which items cannot be used with your current UMD rating when you mouse-over the item's image.

The Fun Part:  The Hardcore Scroll Check

Using a scroll

A scroll can be read if the value check (again, the red halo) is passed. No halo means it can be read.

Reading a scroll by Class

The reading of a scroll requires a d20 dice roll like most other skills.  This dice rolling (or scroll check) is triggered only for certain UMD users.  Here are the three categories of UMD users:

1) Rogue or assassin w/multiclass of at least one level of bard, sorc or wiz: NO scroll check performed.

2) Pure bard or bard multiclass: NO scroll check performed.

3) Rogue or assassin w/o multiclass of at least one level of bard, sorc or wiz: Scroll check performed as described below:

The Scroll Check: Success or Failure

The base DC for a scroll check is 25.  Add to this number the innate spell level of the scroll to calculate the final DC.  

Some spells are cast at different levels by different caster classes, but the innate level is the same for all classes.  This is the level used by the scroll check. (A good example of variable spell levels are found on scrolls of True Seeing.)

Example 1:  Casting a Cantrip Scroll

All Cantrips are Level 0 spells so the DC will be 25 + 0 = 25.  This means a UMD rating of 5 will cast a cantrip scroll with 95% failure.  Only a roll of 20 will succeed.  To guarantee success of all cantrip scrolls requires a UMD rating of 24.

Example 2: Casting a Level 9 Spell Scroll

The DC for Level 9 scrolls is 25 + 9 = 34.  This means a UMD rating of 14 will cast a Level 9 scroll with 95% failure.  Only a roll of 20 will succeed.  To guarantee success of all Level 9 scrolls requires a UMD rating of 33.

Increasing the Success Rate for Low UMD Levels

Besides equipping items with +UMD skill and/or +CHA properties, one of the easiest ways to gain another 10% better chance to succeed is to drink enough Eagle's Splendor pots to raise CHA by at least 4 (+2 UMD).

Any friendly bard level 6 or higher will boost the success rate as will party members who can cast Eagle's Splendor, Aura of Glory or Prayer.

Making Effective Racial UMD Skill Dumps

All UMD classes also have Tumble as a class skill and so the two skills are often dumped on the same level.  However, the CHA modifier affects the UMD level whereas the DEX modifier does not affect the Tumble AC.  Therefore, an adjustment, a delay... must be made when combining both skills into a single dump when the intrinsic CHA is less than 10.  

For dwarves and half-orcs without additional increments of CHA to their racial ability bias, the skill dump of multiclass rogue or assassin must be delayed at least 2 levels.  The minimum dump levels should be on levels: 4, 9, 14, 19, 24, 29, 34 and 39.  

For all other races without additional increments of CHA to their racial ability bias, the skill dump of multiclass rogue or assassin must be delayed at least 1 level.  The minimum dump levels should be on levels: 3, 8, 13, 18, 23, 28, 33 and 38.

Skill Focus in the Bizarro World of NWN

When it comes to focusing in the UMD skill, there are some relationships that defy one's logic.  Please don't ask me to justify the way it works.  I'm only the reporter.
  • Skill Focus: UMD -  Limited to only bard or rogue class levels.
  • Epic Skill Focus: UMD - Limited only to bard, rogue or shadowdancer (yes, you read that last one right) class levels.  Not available as a rogue bonus feat, however.  Of course, to take it on an SD level it would need to meet the 20-rank skill prereq by virtue of one of the 3 qualifying classes.
Apparently, the lowly assassin has been left off of both lists for the sheer evilness of their nature (you are welcome to form your own insight into why Bioware decided this.).

Beware the Enemy Bard!

Even after planning out your UMD allotment, there are no 100% guarantees that your restricted gear will remain usable.  An ultra-level Bard can use its Curse Song to reduce your UMD skill up to 18 ranks.  That means you can be swinging a katana designed specifically for a Weapon Master, loaded with high-value properties and end up unarmed while the song is active, not to mention failure casting most all your scrolls.

In these situations, it is a good idea to quickslot a non-restricted weapon (or other non-restricted gear) just in case the penalty is severe.  Unfortunately, if you happen to be wearing restricted armor, it cannot be swapped during combat so you'll need to either battle naked or else... "Run away! Run away!"

posts.author: darktooth
posts.content:
How many points in UMD should I add in a character with 1 bard lvl and 14 Charisma to able to use all scrolls? I just read an article from nwnwiki and I find it confusing:

“As a general guideline, it takes a UMD score of 1 to use a (class-restricted) scroll with a spell of innate level 0 to 4, UMD 5 to use levels 5 to 8, and UMD 10 for level 9. The requirement for an individual scroll may vary, especially if the caster level is much higher than the minimum for the spell in question.

The additional check is performed after the scroll is used, but before the spell is cast. This check is a standard skill check (d20 + skill level) against a DC of 25 + spell innate level. If this check is passed, the spell is cast normally. If the check is failed, the spell has no effect (but the scroll is still consumed). This check is not rolled (automatic success) if the scroll has no class limitations, the character has at least one bard, sorcerer, or wizard level, or if the character has the spell in question prepared (ready to cast). It does apply to all other characters who have at least one level in rogue, shadowdancer, or assassin, even if that character has a class that is allowed to use the scroll normally.”

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
I believe Bards only need enough UMD to cover the value of the scroll pack to cast without failure in standard NWN.
So a UMD of 10 or 15 modified might be enough.
UMD is modified in some environments. An example being World of Greyhawk. So this may or may not apply.

posts.author: yecori1001
posts.content: Hello, looks like a great guide. Could I get like a confirmation if there is basically a 'max umd' limit that should one aim for? I am having a bard character left with 68 skill points left to allocate. I am wondering If I should go like UMD 42 (+3 charisma) and dump rest the points into other skill or is there any lower optimal limit? In the builds I usually see them going 27 (+3) UMD. I am not sure if I need it maxed. I am going to play a melee bard (26). The other skills I can spend points on are: concentration/listen/persuade, discipline, taunt and other 'good' skills are already sorted out. Would appreciate straight forward answer. :)

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Hello and welcome yecori1001.
Your question is a good one. 
For spell casting a UMD of 10-15 is sufficient, but you will want more.
This is because it depends on the value of the items you wish to equip.

UMD 30 allows to equip items 300k to 1 million gold worth or more depending on the type of emulation.
UMD 35 600k to 1.4million.
UMD 40 allows 1 million to 1.8 million gold worth.

Its the reason why I extracted the data in game and created the table  with enchantment bonuses and values. 
If you look at the table it makes sense that a UMD 30-35 modified would be enough for a +5-6 environment depending on how heavy the enchantment.
If its a heavy magic environment you will want to max UMD to 45 modified as you originally planned to equip all the good items 1.4 to 2.2 million worth and you may also need to find items to boost UMD as well!
But if it isn't as heavy you can make do with less.

Hey yecori1001!
How to spend bard skill points is a very common dilemma. 
There are so many great class skills, concentration, discipline, spellcraft, listen, taunt, tumble, UMD, perform, even stealth if you so desire.

Its honestly never enough :)
